Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Self-Reliant, Autonomous Microsystems for Biophysical Monitoring of Small Animals (Lab-on-a-Bird)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Interdisciplanary Research (IDR) project is to develop self-reliant, self-powered microsystems for autonomous biophysical monitoring. These systems will be applied to the understanding of avian flight biology through the development of a "Lab-on-a-Bird." The approach taken will be to intertwine a number of micro- and nanotechnologies (including biosensors, microfluidics, drug delivery, energy harvesters) with the living animal and will enable on-line monitoring of blood metabolites. The interdisciplinary project combines expertise from the Engineering and Ecology departments at Cornell University with the avian experts at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology.

If successful, the benefits of this research will be two-fold. The first will be from the development of the individual nanotechnology based components and the engineering behind integrating them into a single self-reliant system. It is expected that these systems would have impact well beyond the specific platform here, potentially leading to devices that can provide continuous human health monitoring or become nodes for networks of environmental sensors. The second area of impact will be in the development of an entirely new way of studying avian behavior. For example, these systems could enable us to track physiological changes in a single moving bird thereby yielding priceless information on its internal state and enable an unprecedented understanding of the movement decision-making. Eventually the technologies developed here could be eventually used to provide early warning of viral mutations and outbreaks and to better understand the health of the local ecosystems. A series of targeted curriculum and web-based experiences will also be developed that will engage both high school and adult audiences in learning about bird migration, related physiology, and the technological advances that are making possible new discoveries in these fields.

The project is an Interdisciplinary Research (IDR) Project jointly funded by ENG/CMMI and BIO/IOS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project directly produced three important new developments in small-tag avian sensing capability: 1) the first-ever subcutaneous uric acid sensing tag, 2) the first-ever functional piezoelectrically powered transmitter that can be worn by birds and bats, and 3) the first  solar geolocation module with RF data downlink. We are confident that all of these will be developed further by the biological community. Winkler is already working on further developments of 1 and 3, and 2 suggests a promising avenue for further development of long-term RF deployments on bats.

 

These three developments typify the kinds of developments we initially envisioned for the Lab-on-Bird application, and this work will lead to many further developments in the future. The uric acid sensor has excited interest among avian physiological ecologists who study the regulation of migratory departures.  Birds are thought to leave on their migratory journeys once their stores of fat and protein are large enough, and the uric acid tag provides the first opportunity to monitor the protein state of free-flying wild birds and relate their timing of departure to the dynamics of their protein stores. This could be just the first of many future applications monitoring the physiology of restrained wild birds, which will lead to a much better understanding of their ecology and biology.

 

The piezoelectric energy harvesting system has the potential to open up long-term radio-tracking of bats for the first time because it brings to the fore the possibility of non-solar energy harvesting. Bats fly at night and are usually in shade or dark during the day, thus the ability to harvest energy from a flapping bat could considerably and distinctively increase the active life-time of bat-mounted RF devices. There are many hurdles ahead in piezo manufacturing and robust device design, but this is an area that should be pursued.

 

The new tag designs produced by part of this project’s team have both already elicited a great deal of interest in the biological community, and we anticipate that both could have significant salutary effects on the study of bird movements, both for short-range social network measurement and for longer-range and longer-term studies of dispersal and migration. There is always a premium on smaller device mass, and solar geolocation still outperforms GPS substantially in terms of number of attainable fixes per gram of device weight. And the advances we are making on solar energy harvesting will likely influence all of our tag designs in the future.

 

Our group has given real-world engineering experience to a large number of undergraduate, masters, and PhD level Mechanical, Electrical, and Computer Science majors at Cornell. Many of these have already gone on to positions in industry. By working on systems to be used by biologists in the field, these students gain distinctive real-world experience, drawing on multiple sub-disciplines and combining them, exposing themselves to many of the same problems and scenarios posed by modern electronic systems in industry.
